frameDefinitions: An Agent has attempted to achieve a Goal, and the actual outcome of the Agent's action has been resolved, so that it either specifically matches the Agent's intent (e.g. success) or does not match it (e.g. failure).
The words in this frame describe the death of a Protagonist.
An Employee voluntarily leaves the service of an Employer.
A Sleeper goes from wakefulness to an altered state of consciousness where they are largely unaware of their environment.
An Agent adjusts an Instrument to enable it to interact directly with a difficult-to-access Target_location.
A Performer has a certain Role in a Performance and plays their part by following the directions in the Script for that particular Role.
frameExamples: He <t>pulled</t> <t>off</t> his April Fool's Day prank by the barest of margins .
The machine was not switched off, but Mr. Lavelle <t>died</t> of natural causes, police said.
Leah <t>quit</t> her job after one month because of an evil force.
If you <t>aim</t> your weapons somewhere else , I 'll be more likely to talk .
Margaret Thatcher <t>played</t> Juliet in a school play.
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> makes an attempt to achieve a <fen>Goal</fen>.
The <fen>Goal</fen> is what the <fen>Agent</fen> attempts to achieve.
A participant function in a particular event or in events of a particular kind.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the attempt succeeds or fails.
The place where an attempt succeeds or fails.
The role <fen>Protagonist</fen> is the being or entity that dies.  With verbs in this frame, the <fen>Protagonist</fen> is the External Argument.
The role <fen>Time</fen> denotes when the dying or killing occurs.
The role <fen>Place</fen> indicates where the death takes place.
The person who is obligated to perform some task in order to receive compensation.
The person (or institution) in whose employ  the <fen>Employee</fen> stood.
The Field that one works in.
The label given to a particular type of service that the employer quits.
This role identifies the Time when an <fen>Employee</fen> quits the employment of the <fen>Employer</fen>.
This role identifies the place where the <fen>Employee</fen> quits the employment of the <fen>Employer</fen>.
The <fen>Sleeper</fen> is the entity that falls asleep.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> where the event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the event occurs.
The individual that manipulates the <fen>Instrument</fen> to enable interaction with the <fen>Targeted</fen>.
The <fen>Targeted</fen> is the entity located in an indirectly accessible location relative to the <fen>Agent</fen>.
The object manipulated by the <fen>Agent</fen> in order to interact with the <fen>Targeted</fen>.
The location that the <fen>Agent</fen> wishes to ready the <fen>Instrument</fen> to access.
The <fen>Activity</fen> is undertaken by the <fen>Agent</fen> and is directed towards the <fen>Targeted</fen> or <fen>Target_location</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> takes aim.
The place where the <fen>Agent</fen> aims at the <fen>Targeted</fen>.
The <fen>Audience</fen> experiences the <fen>Performance</fen>.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical entity or channel used by the <fen>Performer</fen> to transmit the <fen>Performance</fen> to the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The <fen>Performer</fen>s generates the <fen>Performance</fen> which  the <fen>Audience</fen> perceives.
The <fen>Performer</fen> provides an experience for the <fen>Audience</fen>.
The music which may be performed in the <fen>Performance</fen>, either in isolation or accompanying actions and speech.

The (usually written) directions which instruct the <fen>Performer</fen>s on what actions to perform, when, and how.  It has many different names depending on the <fen>Type</fen> of <fen>Performance</fen> including <ment>script</ment>, <ment>screenplay</ment>, <ment>libretto</ment>, <ment>book</ment>, and <ment>choreography</ment>.
This role indicates the subtype of <fen>Performance</fen>, including <ment>dance</ment>, <ment>theater</ment>, <ment>film</ment>, etc.

<fen>Role</fen> identifies one of the possible relations that the <fen>Performer</fen> can have to the <fen>Performance</fen>.  The <fen>Role</fen> (s) a <fen>Performer</fen> has in the <fen>Performance</fen> will determine which parts of the <fen>Script</fen> should be performed by the <fen>Performer</fen>, as the <fen>Script</fen> is written in terms of which <fen>Role</fen> (s) each set of instructions applies to.  In the fields of theater, movies, ballet, and opera, a <fen>Role</fen> generally corresponds to a character in the story of the <fen>Script</fen>, while other types of performance may use more general <fen>Role</fen>s like <ment>lead violinist</ment>.
The person that performs alongside Performer2.
The person that is also in the Performance, alongside Performer1.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when an event occurs.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> an event occurs.
listRoleExamples: If you don't succeed <fex>in your subterfuge</fex>, then report back for further orders.
Benedikt was successful <fex>as a master brewer of beer</fex>.
<fex>On the bridge</fex> he succeeded in putting the wig on the corpse.
Your father passed away <fex>about four minutes ago</fex>.
Your father passed away <fex>in his hospital bed</fex>.
He replaces Michael Lawrie, 50, who quit <fex>IBM</fex> to run Siebel.
Actually Iquit <fex>in the lobby</fex> before I got to my office.
I tried to target <fex>his left thigh</fex> .
If you target <fex>towards the bridge</fex> , make sure to avoid the church .
<fex>The attack</fex> targeted a village south of here.
He co-starred <fex>with Matt Perry</fex> in Tool 3.
Who co-starred <fex>with Glen Close</fex> in that space opera thingy?
